data.title: Two Anti-Summer Songs by The Kinks
data.meta_description: For over half a century, my favorite album to kick off the summer season has been The Kinks Are the Village Green Preservation Society. The songs are cheerier than those of other Kinks masterpieces…
data.text:
Songstories challenge from Christopher Robin: Your Go-To Summer Song

For over half a century, my favorite album to kick off the summer season has been The Kinks Are the Village Green Preservation Society. The songs are cheerier than those of other Kinks masterpieces (though with a serious dose of wistfulness). In spite of the cheerfulness, however, the album does not simplistically celebrate the hazy, golden moments of summer, but reflects on what’s probably the central subject of Ray Davies major works since Face to Face (1966): our inability to accept the impermanence of happiness.

Not surprisingly, the dominant emotion is a kind of warm comfort from nostalgic musings. The final track “People Take Pictures,” however, takes all those previous indulgences and tosses them in the wastebasket. Nostalgia for a lost past (symbolized by summer) is revealed to be cloying and self-defeating.

Almost 20 years later, Ray Davies takes an even darker perspective in “Summer’s Gone,” from Word of Mouth (1984), suggesting that the root of our unhappiness isn’t the natural change of seasons (the transience of life) but our failure to celebrate the moment —by refusing to appreciate its eventual loss.
